newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: FOCUS - NZ power giants make peace to set up venture.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - NZ power giants make peace to set up venture.

text.p: Two heavyweights in the New Zealand electricity industry ended a bitter takeover battle for Power New Zealand on Tuesday to instead form joint control.

Auckland power distributor Mercury Energy and the Kansas-based UtiliCorp United Inc have been slugging it out for 2-1/2 years for control of listed Power New Zealand, Mercury's rival for power distribution in Auckland.
The two buried their differences saying they had formed a joint venture to control PNZ and simultaneously announced a NZ$6 a share offer to minorities.
Together, Mercury and Utilicorp own 64 percent of PNZ.
Their battle saw each bid the other up from a starting price in 1994 of NZ$3.40 per share to NZ$10 per share offered to a group of local authority holders controlling 7.1 percent of PNZ.
A bid at NZ$6 per share values PNZ at over NZ$900 million.

"The proposal was a practical, commercial solution to the impasse which had developed over ownership and merger. It ends the long-running share battle and paves the way for a new era," the companies said in a joint statement.
Mercury chief executive Wayne Gilbert said in an interview with Reuters that the settlement of the PNZ issue cleared the way for Mercury to list on the New Zealand exchange.
Listing had been delayed because of problems caused by the protracted takeover bid.
"The float now is certain and it will be sooner rather than later," he said.
Gilbert said the preparation of a prospectus would mean the float would come next year rather than this year. The company's board is meeting this week to consider the issue, he added.
"Reaching an accommodation with each other was a better proposition than continuing to stage a battle in which neither of us could prevail," Gilbert said of the today's deal.
The joint venture would need permission from the anti-trust Commerce Commission for the proposal to proceed.
The companies jointly will have nearly 45 percent of the total retail electricity market.
But clearance appears probable. The commission in 1994 gave Mercury permission to proceed with its takeover offer arguing there were enough other distributors to offer competition.
Gilbert noted that Power and Mercury would remain separate entities and a merger in future was not part of the deal.
He said planned financial benefits would be very substantial but less that the annual NZ$30 million estimated from a merger.
As well as the Auckland market, the joint venture will gain control of WEL Energy, the distributing company in the neighbouring Waikato district.
Utilicorp had 39.5 percent of WEL and said it would sell that holding into the joint venture with Mercury. PNZ also has 10 percent of WEL.
Utilicorp launched the venture through Utilicorp New Zealand, controlled 79 percent by itself and 21 percent by the private Todd Corporation.
Utilicorp Senior Vice-President, Australasia, Paul Perkins said the decision to enter the joint venture underlined its commitment to New Zealand.
"New Zealand is an excellent market with great opportunities," he said.
He declined to say whether Utilicorp would become involved in other ventures with Mercury such as a 114 megawatt power station Mercury is jointly building in South Auckland with Canada's TransAlta.
"We have enough on our plate now," Perkins said.
The board of PNZ will meet with its major shareholders on Thursday, afterwhich it expects to issue statement.
